climbs.name: Memorial Day Route
climbs.fa: D. Boyd & D. Turville, 1970  FFA:  J. Donini & M. Ward, 1978

content.description: An obscure, yet adventurous line that deserves mention, the Memorial Day Route follows the obvious weaknesses on this seldom-climbed formation near the mouth of LCC.  Begin at a large, keyed-in spike of rock beneath the prominent roof.  A few gritty moves gain an undercling that traverses leftward past a pin, then pulls a small roof to a ramp.  Belay from a comfortable, low-angled stance located just beneath the start of the Mouth Variation (.11).  Step across a gaping chasm and into the cleft just beneath the obvious Mouth slot.  You may encounter a bit of dirt and/or moss--most of the holds were cleaned during our ascent--on the thin edges as the route meanders in and out of the corner past two pins.  Pull out of the corner then onto a slab with a two pin anchor.  The final pitch climbs a right-diagonalling crack through an overlap, then past a scary flake resting precariously on a ledge below the final steep, wide crack.  Belay from the ledge directly above, or continue up the wild, featured slab to anchor in the trees.  Get after it!
content.protection: Bring a standard rack with cams from micros to fists--doubles may be useful.
content.location: Approach the Memorial Day Buttress from either the Bongeater or the Crescent Crack Buttress; either approach will involve at least some bushwhacking through the scrub oak...  Descend from atop the third pitch--a double rope rappel from slings in trees will put you on the ground just uphill and to the east of the start of the route.

content.description:
Is it worth hiking up there? Its a good option after

Bong Eater

or

The Burner

routes, but no classic for sure.

Lieback up the lower angle 5.9 corner with great feet and gear to reach the first bolt, after which a fun leg swing mantle move gets you to bolt 2 and a bomber rest. Here, the route diverges two ways. Both are excellent, so do both. Your first option is to head straight up, clipping a bolt over your head and doing a difficult undercling to slapping a wide groove while mantling action onto the slab whereupon you find yourself at the chains. Tricky.

Option 2, and I believe the original way, is to continue traversing out right past 2 more pitons, then pulling the roof again by mantling with a decent chickenhead for a handhold. This felt a bit easier than the direct option, only because it was more obvious.
content.protection: Mixed gear/bolts. You will need max 3 cams no bigger than .5 camalot to reach the first bolt after which its all fixed gear to the top. 2 bolt anchor. Recommend belaying 2nd up from top at heinous rope drag ensues while lowering.
content.location:
While this route is located under the

Memorial Day Buttress

area and most start from

Crescent

, I find it easier to approach from

Bong Eater

. Hike up to

Bong Eater

from the Park and Ride, then schwak directly east to the boulder talus gully. Hike straight up this talus to the crag, jungle thrashing the last 20 feet to reach the belay stance. Its a right facing corner with roofs at the top on darker granite rock. Look for the bolts. This route sits alone, below and southwest of Memorial proper.

content.description: Start on the left side of belay ledge up through a tree and into a right facing wide crack. Thrutch up a couple body lengths until it is possible to clip a bolt on the slab above. Wander up slab with occasionally fun moves, clipping a couple of bolts along the way, and into low-angle flared cracks. As the crack pinches down to a seam a couple of funky pitons appear. A bolt protects the final slab crux. Belay from a sturdy tree above the route. Walk off or rap with 2 ropes. Plenty of exfoliating rock but it's solid when you need it.
content.protection: Standard rack, optional #5 for the wide. Lots of runners.
content.location: Way up on the slabby west face of Memorial Day Buttress. Scramble and thrash along the base until an obvious chockstone cave blocks the way. There is an exit hole on the right side of the cave that puts you right at the belay. Route starts in the wide crack above.

content.description:
Make a few easy but unprotected face moves off the belay ledge until good pro is reached at about 15 feet. Mantel a fun mini "roof" and head up and right following a crack feature to the first bolt. Continue up and right through a cool wavy section with sparse pro, gaining a flared handcrack above. When the crack disappears, slab up and right past 2 more bolts and get established in another flaring crack that is a bit steeper than the first.

The original finish seemed to go up and right above the final crack to a large tree. I found kitty litter and no protection that way so I went left instead, clipping a piton in a dihedral and moving straight left to a pine tree belay. Bolts on the route look like quarter inchers with SMC hangers. Walk off or rap with 2 ropes.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #4, lots of runners
content.location: On the west face of Memorial Day Buttress. Starts right of High School Drop Out off the same belay ledge.

climbs.name: Dave Anderson Memorial Route
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Jim Howe, 24 March 1998 , started with Dave the previous Fall

content.description:
Dave Anderson had scoped this line and envisioned all the pitches long before he and I went up there late in the Fall of 1997 to climb it. Dave was a true off-width master and had discovered many of the early gems in the Wasatch, including those on Memorial Day Buttress.

We climbed two of the pitches that day and were a bit chased off due to impending darkness and windy cold weather. Nevertheless, we had a great adventure. The unfinished route (with the two pitches) made its way into the Ruckman guide that was published in the Spring of 1998. It was called El Viento Es Frio (Spanish for "the wind is cold"....which Dave and I had decided to call the climb after shivering in that November snowstorm.

Dave was later tragically killed while being rescued after suffering from serious injuries in an avalanche while skiing in Pink Pine in January 1998. The AirMed helicopter crashed and all perished. Jim Howe, another friend of Dave's and mine, thought it a nice idea to finish it and give it the new name. Ironically, after doing this climb together, Jim and I went on to work as Flight Nurses later for AirMed.

I don't know if it has been repeated so the details seem vague now. But it is easy to find.

After gaining the base of the Buttress, trend east and up around the corner. This climbs the multiple massive roofs up the impressive East Face.

Pitch #1: Ascend a right facing dihedral with a good steep crack to a sloping belay stance. 5.8

Pitch #2: The dihedral turns into some thin nailing through a roof and traverses out right to a two bolt belay under a series of roofs. (Dave always thought this would go free someday, probably by him!...we were shivering at this point.) A1-A2.

Pitch #3: A few bolts assault the steep overlap above the belay to another crack that diagonals right and up. 5.8, A1.

Pitch #4: Continue up some more mixed climbing to another two-bolt belay and rappel station. 5.?

Rappel the route.
content.protection: Some pitons and bolts left fixed, but plan on taking a good aid rack. The fixed bolts are 3/8" x 2.5" Rawls.
content.location: As noted above. This is the East Face of Memorial Day Buttress. I believe it remains the lone route on this face.

content.description:
After doing about 20 minutes of bushwhacking a casual route is what is needed. This route is locate 100 feet to the left of Aggression and follows a mostly independent line.

P1) Start of a left leaning crack into a right leaning crack that cuts through the roof. Pull the roof and belay at the base of the big corner. 5.11-

P2) Start up the corner stemming your way to the big flake that sticks outs creates an off width. Do a few friction moves to gain access above the flake and continue up the dihedral and cracks to a ledge. Belay here. 5.10-

P3) Climb up easy hand and fist cracks to a ledge 5.7. Belay here.

P4) Either climb a easy pitch to the summit block or climb the bolted variation out to the left (The Eyebrow 11a)

Descent: Walk of to the north of the route and to the base.
content.protection: Doubles to a #2 camalot and lots of runners, A single 3" or 4.5" piece may be helpful but not required. 70m rope is helpful but not required as well.

content.description:
Short. This one makes

Plumb Line

seem like a full 60m pitch. 6-7 finger locks, a few .3 camalots and your on top. Not a gimme, but the length makes it an easy onsight for your ego. Could be bouldered honestly if you feel good about it. I chose not to but its that short. Do a couple laps continuously to actually make it seem like a real climb.
content.protection: single set tcu's, small nuts. Completely worthless rusted piece of ___ bolt that should not be used sits above the ledge as a severely not recommended anchor. Build a nest of small gear atop the crack to lower off, or lasso a small bushel(scary?) then when you're finished clean it and downclimb the 5.5 crack to the right.
content.location: Hike up huge hill to the memorial day buttress. This is the obvious short right leaning finger crack that ends in lots of bushels atop a small ledge. Not hard to find. Can be seen from the road if you look hard enough.
